channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Bombs Hit Sole Civilian Airport in Libyan Capital
item.description: Commanders from Operation Dignity said they ordered the strikes because the airport and the capital had fallen under the control of the rival coalition Libya Dawn.
item.dc:creator: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Leading Surgeon Is Accused of Misconduct in Experimental Transplant Operations
item.description: A doctor who is considered a pioneer in the field of regenerative medicine has denied carrying out innovative operations without ethical approvals.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Kunstmuseum Bern Obtains Trove From Gurlitt Collection
item.description: In agreeing to take the gift of more than 1,000 works, the Kunstmuseum Bern said it would ensure that any seized art in the trove was returned to its rightful owner.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: “Street Tram,” by Bernhard Kretschmar, is one of the works in the trove that Cornelius Gurlitt kept for years in his Munich apartment.

item.title: Israeli Police Arrest Arab Suspects in Two Jerusalem Stabbings of Jews
item.description: The police said they were investigating the stabbings as a possible terrorist attack that extended the spate of religious violence roiling Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: U.S. and Allies Extend Iran Nuclear Talks by 7 Months
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry says “new ideas surfaced,” as a temporary agreement remains in place and Iran gets $5 billion more in sanctions relief.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Mr. Kerry with Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif of Iran on Monday in Vienna.

item.title: U.N. Report Shows an Increase in Trafficking of Children
item.description: One in three human trafficking victims is a child, most victims are female, and traffickers operate with wide impunity, the report on modern-day slavery said.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Britain Plans to Expand Police Powers With New Antiterror Legislation
item.description: The proposed measure would include travel restrictions and would make it illegal for insurance companies to reimburse ransom payments for hostage releases.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Further Strains in Unresolved War Between Armenia and Azerbaijan Over Disputed Territory
item.description: Armenia announced funerals for three soldiers killed by Azerbaijan forces who downed a helicopter over Nagorno-Karabakh, the focus of their conflict.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Hagel Resigns Under Pressure as Global Crises Test Pentagon
item.description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel was asked to resign his post, officials said, as President Obama’s national security team has struggled to stay ahead of an onslaught of global crises.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel and President Obama at a White House news conference announcing Mr. Hagel's resignation on Monday.

item.title: 2 Foreign Soldiers Are Said to Have Been Killed in Afghanistan
item.description: The attack, reported by Afghan officials, occurred when a bomb hidden in the median strip of an avenue in the capital went off.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Afghan Women Are Excluded From Peace Overtures to Taliban, Report Says
item.description: The document by Oxfam echoes the worries of many women that a deal with religiously conservative insurgents will wipe out women’s gains.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: A Struggle for the Soul of Hong Kong’s Protest Movement
item.description: Some demonstrators have grown impatient with the milder path and argue that only stronger action can win concessions from the Hong Kong government.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Wong Yeung-tat and his organization, Civic Passion, argue that only stronger action will win concessions from Hong Kong.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Kevin Niu on Movies and the Hunger for Horror in China
item.description: Despite being about to receive his Ph.D. in physics from Harvard, Kevin Niu plans to eschew the academic life to follow his calling in the entertainment industry.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Kevin Niu, Ph.D. student in physics and producer of the horror movie "Abattoir."

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Considers How to Harness the Wind to Blow Away Pollution
item.description: In a plan inspired by research on urban heat islands, city planners are looking at ways to create corridors that encourage wind flow through the Chinese capital.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Smog returned to Beijing after emergency measures to clear the air during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting were lifted.

item.title: Gabriel García Márquez’s Archive Goes to University of Texas
item.description: Gabriel García Márquez’s archive has been acquired by the University of Texas and includes manuscripts, correspondence, photos and personal artifacts related to his important books.
item.category: Ransom, Harry, Center, The University of Texas at Austin
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER SCHUESSLER

item.title: Memo From Europe: Nations Ponder How to Handle European Fighters Returning From Jihad
item.description: A young man who came back to Germany from fighting in Syria has confessed in court and said he would like “to live a totally normal life.”
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Fish Vendors Attacked
item.description: Boko Haram militants have killed 48 fish vendors in northeastern Nigeria, near the border with Chad, the leader of the local fish traders’ association said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing: Burkina Faso: Military Controls Key Posts in New Government
item.description: Transitional leaders have agreed on a new government to guide the country to elections next year, allocating several key cabinet posts to members of the military.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Despite Persecution, Guardian of Lake Tai Spotlights China’s Polluters
item.description: Despite pressure from Beijing, factories continue to dump toxic waste into waterways because the cost of violating the rules is lower than the cost of compliance.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Iran Grants Bail to Woman From Britain Held 5 Months
item.description: Ghoncheh Ghavami, 25, who has dual citizenship, is appealing a one-year sentence for a conviction that has been linked to activism.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Graft Hobbles Iraq’s Military in Fighting ISIS
item.description: The Iraqi military and police forces had been so pillaged by their own leadership that they all but collapsed this spring in the face of the advancing Islamic State fighters.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Iraqi Army member reporting to be reinstated for duty in September, after many deserted in the face of the ISIS onslaught.

item.title: Tunisia Vote for Leader Likely to Go to a Runoff
item.description: Beji Caid Essebsi, a former prime minister, and Moncef Marzouki, the interim president, were leading but neither was expected to win a majority.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: A polling station in Tunis, the capital, on Sunday. Beji Caid Essebsi, a former prime minister, and Moncef Marzouki, the interim president, were leading in Tunisia’s first free presidential election.

item.title: Iran Nuclear Negotiators, Facing Key Differences, Weigh Extending Deadline
item.description: Western and Iranian officials said on Sunday that with issues still unresolved on an agreement to curb Iran’s nuclear program, they might consider prolonging the talks beyond Monday.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students demonstrated in front of Tehran’s only nuclear test reactor as Iranian and Western diplomats met in Vienna.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Good News on Energy
item.description: Reducing greenhouse gas emissions is simply another step in the transition to cleaner energy.
item.dc:creator: By RALPH CAVANAGH

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Judaism Must Embrace the Convert
item.description: Our people believe in inclusiveness as well as chosenness.
item.dc:creator: By SHMULY YANKLOWITZ
